persona.name: Erin Sora Park-Harrington

occupation.title: Lead Preschool Paraprofessional / Part-time Freelance Front-End Web Developer
occupation.organization: Bright Beginnings Community Preschool (morning/early afternoon), freelance client work evenings and weekends
occupation.description:
Erin works roughly 28–32 hours a week in a community-based preschool program for 3- to 5-year-olds as a lead paraprofessional, responsible for classroom routines, daily lesson facilitation, snack and nap supervision, parent communication for her group, basic developmental screenings, and coordinating field trips. She plans play-based activities that scaffold early literacy, social-emotional learning, and cultural inclusion (incorporating Korean stories and songs). She holds basic first aid/CPR and child safe-sleep and choking-prevention certifications.

In the late afternoons/evenings she does freelance front-end work: small business websites, Wordpress maintenance, basic responsive HTML/CSS, and accessibility tweaks. Most freelance clients are neighborhood small-business owners (bakeries, tutors, therapists) and occasional friends; she manages invoices, client communication, and small project timelines. She balances her workload to protect family time and is skilled at toggling between the hands-on, sensory preschool environment and focused laptop work. Her main challenges are unpredictable preschool coverage needs (sick days), lack of employer-provided maternity leave buffer, and keeping freelance income steady without overworking evenings.

persona.residence: Oakmont neighborhood, Portland, OR (urban renter in a 2-bedroom apartment)
persona.education: Associate of Applied Science, Early Childhood Education (community college). Completed a part-time web development bootcamp (front-end focused) and several continuing-education workshops on trauma-informed classroom practice and child development.
long_term_goals: Raise children who are confident, curious, and kind while preserving both sides of their multicultural heritage.
Buy a modest single-family home in a child-friendly neighborhood within 7-10 years to provide stability and a small yard.
Transition over the next 5 years from split roles (preschool teacher + freelance tech work) into a stable hybrid job with predictable hours and better benefits.
Establish a small, part-time childcare cooperative with other neighborhood parents that blends early literacy, bilingual exposure (Korean and English), and nature play.
Build a retirement cushion and emergency fund sufficient for six months of expenses and reduce lingering student and credit-card debt.
Be active in local schools and city planning to improve parks and transit safety for families.
Keep learning practical skills (basic plumbing, car maintenance, advanced Excel) and a creative skill as an outlet (sewing, simple woodworking).
Create yearly family traditions that mix Korean and Midwestern/West Coast holidays so children grow up bicultural.
Model sustainable, pragmatic consumer choices for the kids (reduce-food-waste habits, thrift shopping, mindful consumption).
Maintain emotional resilience and stable mental health so parenting does not come at the cost of the caretaker’s wellbeing.

style.overall: Warm, practical, slightly rushed but intentionally gentle. Her clothing is comfortable and kid-friendly—stretch jeans, cozy cardigans, weatherproof boots. Prefers layered outfits for easy breastfeeding/holding toddlers and quickly stepping outside for playground runs. Carries a well-organized diaper bag that doubles as a work bag.
style.speech_and_accents: General American accent with slight vowel qualities influenced by family Korean phrases and visits to relatives. Speaks quickly when excited, softens voice when consoling children. Has a habit of using short, direct sentences when giving instructions to kids ('Hands in your lap, please.'). Often code-switches between informal parenting language and more formal, task-oriented language for work emails.
style.mannerisms: Smiles easily, often tilts head when listening. Tends to tuck hair behind her ear when thinking. Uses lots of small affirmations with children ("I see you," "Thank you for sharing") and adults. Fidgets with a plain silver ring when anxious. Uses phone as a notebook and habitually sets multiple timers (for cooking, naps, meetings).
style.register_and politeness: Generally informal and warm with peers and neighbors, courteous and concise with bureaucracies (doctors, school admin). Uses humor to defuse parenting stress. Comfortable advocating for her children in professional settings but tries to avoid confrontation unless necessary.
style.digital behavior: Typifies the urban, connected parent: frequently replies to messages in short bursts, uses voice-to-text for quick replies, posts photos of kids sparingly to family-only threads, actively checks local moms' groups and parenting forums for recommendations.
style.interaction_preferences: Prefers one-on-one conversations and small, mixed-age playgroups. In meetings, she listens more than talks but will speak up with practical suggestions.

traits: Nurturing and patient in caregiving contexts, but pragmatic and task-focused when juggling schedules.
Resourceful and hands-on — enjoys solving logistical puzzles (childcare swaps, packing for trips).
Emotionally attuned to children's needs; reads mood shifts quickly and steps in to regulate.
Prone to parental guilt and overthinking choices like screen time or daycare options.
Sociable in community spaces (parks, preschool pick-up), forming small, reliable networks.
Values fairness and inclusion; attentive to microaggressions and advocates gently but firmly.
Sometimes anxious about finances and long-term stability; this drives prudent decision making.
Enjoys small pleasures — a good americano, quiet podcasts during a walk, community potlucks.
Has a dry, self-deprecating sense of humor and uses it to connect with other parents.
Slightly perfectionistic about routines; dislikes chaos but tolerates controlled messes for the sake of play.
Curious about tech and how tools can make life easier but skeptical of trends that seem unnecessary.
personality.notes_on_big_five: Openness: enjoys new recipes, children's books and occasional travel; Conscientiousness: strong planner, lists and calendars; Extraversion: moderately social—energized by small groups but drained by large gatherings; Agreeableness: cooperative and helpful, often the one organizing childcare swaps; Neuroticism: occasional worry about money and parenting choices, but manages with routines and support.

general_interests: Parenting blogs and evidence-based child development resources
Simple, nourishing cooking (one-pot meals, slow-cooker stews, banchan basics)
Podcasts on parenting, local politics, and practical entrepreneurship
Local food markets and small bakeries
DIY projects—sewing simple clothes, mending, making sensory play kits
Streaming family-friendly shows in the evening (animated educational series)
Photographing everyday family moments on her phone
Easy home organization and small-space storage solutions
Thrift shopping and upcycling children's clothes
Play-based educational toys (blocks, wooden puzzles, open-ended art supplies)
Simple yoga/stretch routines for postpartum recovery
Community volunteer days at the preschool or neighborhood cleanups
Mindful parenting techniques (breathing exercises, naming emotions)
vacation_preferences_and_children: Short trips (2–5 nights) are preferred to minimize disruption to routines and naps.
Prefers destinations within a 4–6 hour drive or a single short flight to avoid long transfers with young kids.
Chooses accommodations with separate sleeping areas or suite-style rooms so children can nap on schedule.
Likes rental homes or family suites with kitchen facilities to manage picky eaters and bedtime routines.
Beach and calm lake spots are favored for toddlers—sand play, easy outdoor meals, and gentle water play.
Parks/backyard-accessible rentals are ideal so children can run safely while adults relax.
Avoids overly scheduled tours; prefers flexible days with one planned activity per day.
Looks for destinations with nearby pediatric facilities and a pharmacy as reassurances.
Brings familiar items: white-noise machine/app, favorite stuffed toy, portable blackout curtains, stroller, two car seats if driving.
Schedules travel around sleep windows—leaves after nap rather than during bedtime when possible.
Will split childcare responsibilities with spouse so each adult gets a short break, and coordinates with grandparents if they travel together.
Enjoys mixing cultural exploration with kid-focused activities (a short museum visit + a park picnic).
Packs plenty of snacks and a small bin of quiet toys and board books for transit.
Likes family-friendly resorts with childcare options for an afternoon so the couple can have a dinner out occasionally.
Dislikes crowded, overstimulating tourist hubs when kids are small; prefers off-peak travel seasons.
Values destinations that reflect both cultural heritages (e.g., visits to a Korean cultural center or community when feasible).
Practical about airfare—willing to pay a bit more for flights that avoid uncomfortable layovers with kids.
Uses local parenting groups and reviews to vet restaurants and safety of beaches/play areas.
Prefers travel insurance that covers small family emergencies.
Seeks low-friction travel gear: travel stroller that folds compactly, car seat with airplane approval, and a sling for nap walks.
food_and_cafe_preferences: Prefers cafés with kid corners or outdoor seating—values table space for children's coloring books.
Favorite coffee: oat-milk latte, medium roast; drinks decaf in late afternoons to avoid caffeine affecting sleep.
Likes light savory snacks (egg sandwiches, avocado toast) and pastries from local bakeries.
Avoids overly spicy foods with toddlers; brings sippy cups and small plates to share.
On weekdays, quick, savory breakfasts: savory oatmeal, egg muffins or kimbap-style rolls.
Enjoys trying new local bakeries and supporting immigrant-owned small businesses.
Prefers cafés with good Wi-Fi for occasional freelance work but chooses quiet corners to avoid disrupting other patrons.
Keeps a stash of non-perishable snack bars in the diaper bag for emergencies.
Enjoys weekend brunches with other parents but often arrives early to avoid crowds.
Likes sharing banchan-style small plates at family dinners to expose kids to diverse tastes.
media_and_tech_preferences: Heavy social-media user for parenting groups: active on a private Facebook parenting group, Instagram for sharing family milestones privately, and Pinterest for craft ideas.
Streams children’s shows selectively (prefers short, educational programs and music-based series).
Uses apps: Cozi (family calendar), Venmo (shared household expenses), Headspace (short guided breaths), and a local ride-share app.
Buys parenting gear after researching 3–4 reviews and asking local groups for hands-on feedback.
Values privacy settings and minimal ad-tracking for kids' content; skeptical of smart toys that collect data.
likes: Simple rituals: family bedtime stories, Saturday pancakes, small neighborhood walks after dinner.
Neighborhood potlucks and library story times.
Small acts of kindness from neighbors (lending a cup of sugar, sharing a recipe).
Practical baby/kid gear that is durable and easy to clean.
Korean comfort foods (mild kimchi stew, japchae) and American comfort staples (mac and cheese, roasted chicken).
Handmade gifts from her children—crayon drawings prized and displayed on the fridge.
Local farmers market produce and seasonal fruit for snacks.
Informal playdates rather than rigid schedules.
dislikes: Unnecessary parenting shaming and rigid, judgmental advice.
Long airport layovers and cramped flights with toddlers.
Products marketed solely to parents that are overpriced and low-quality.
Overly loud indoor chain restaurants during toddler meltdown windows.
Endless screen time for kids; tries to set gentle boundaries without being punitive.

beliefs: Early childhood is critical—play is the primary way children learn social and cognitive skills.
Bilingual exposure in early years fosters flexibility, cultural identity, and long-term cognitive benefits.
Access to safe public parks and libraries is essential for child development and community cohesion.
Vaccinations are important; science-backed health guidance should steer parenting choices.
Parental mental health matters as much as children's health; parents should seek help without stigma.
Work-life balance is a structural issue; employers should offer predictable schedules and parental leave.
Community childcare cooperatives and shared resources can reduce costs and increase social support.
Quality child care requires trained staff and fair wages; undervaluing childcare staff is harmful to society.
Renting is often practical in early parenting years; homeownership is a long-term goal but not an immediate priority.
Financial prudence (emergency savings, frugal but intentional spending) reduces parenting stress.
Routine provides children security; however, flexibility is needed to respond to children's moods and health.
Parenting advice should be evidence-based and culturally sensitive rather than prescriptive.
Screen time in small doses, supported by co-viewing and interactive apps, can be educational; passive unlimited screen time is harmful.
Mealtime rituals and shared family dinners are important even when schedules are hectic.
Minimalist, durable toys foster creativity more than battery-operated flashy toys.
Grandparents can be both invaluable support and sources of different childrearing perspectives; navigate respectfully.
Local public transit should be safe and accessible for families who rely on it with strollers.
Civic participation (voting, attending school board meetings) impacts community resources for children.
Childhood illnesses are stressful but manageable with good medical advice and home care; panic rarely helps.
Parental guilt is ubiquitous but not a useful metric—actions matter more than imagined failures.
Children model behavior; adults should demonstrate empathy, patience, and respect in daily interactions.
Affordable healthcare and mental health resources are societal priorities.
Sustainability matters—reducing waste and teaching kids about reuse is part of education.
Cooking with children (age-appropriate tasks) builds skills and confidence.
Polite, consistent boundaries help children navigate social expectations and feel safe.
Economic inequality shapes children's outcomes; supporting local equity initiatives matters.
Traditional gender roles need not define childcare; shared domestic labor leads to healthier relationships.
Parent groups are powerful for exchanging practical tips—realistic, nonjudgmental groups are most helpful.
Data privacy for children's products is important; skeptical of toys or apps that collect unnecessary data.
Public libraries and free community resources are underused treasures; the city should fund them better.
skills: Early childhood pedagogy: lesson planning for preschool-aged children, scaffolding play for language development.
Classroom management and positive behavioral supports for toddlers and preschoolers.
Basic pediatric first aid and CPR certified.
Front-end web development: HTML5, CSS3, basic JavaScript, responsive design principles, Wordpress administration.
Simple troubleshooting for home networks and smart devices used for streaming family media.
Practical organizational skills: family calendaring, shared expense tracking, packing efficiently for trips.
Basic Korean conversational skills—can read and pronounce Hangul, sing children's songs, and read simple picture books.
Cooking family-friendly meals with modest budgets, batch cooking, and meal-planning.
Negotiation and communication with school staff, landlords, and service providers.
Small-scale project management: juggling multiple freelance projects, client expectations, and childcare.
Time-blocking and micro-tasking to protect family time.
Basic sewing and mending clothing, upcycling children's clothes.
Guided mindfulness and breathing techniques used in classroom calming corners.
Community organizing: coordinating playdates, potlucks, and a preschool fundraiser.
Budgeting skills: balancing household budgets with irregular freelance income and tracking expenses.

general: Often talks in a sing-song voice to babies and uses short, descriptive language with toddlers ('red ball', 'big truck').
Sets multiple alarms for daily routines: wake-up, meal times, nap windows, laundry cycles.
Keeps a battery of preparedness items—spare clothes, snacks, bandaids—in the diaper bag.
Checks local parent groups on Facebook each morning for announcements or gear swaps.
Schedules weekly 'reset' time on Sunday evenings to meal prep and plan the week’s logistics.
Prefers to resolve conflicts with calm explanation and modeling empathy rather than punitive tactics.
Juggles phone-based freelance tasks in 20–45 minute blocks during children's nap times.
Maintains a rotating menu of go-to recipes to reduce dinner decision fatigue.
Often volunteers for reading time or snack prep at preschool because she values connection and modeling parental involvement.
Uses collaborative spreadsheets with spouse for shared budgeting and family calendars.

morning: Wakes at 6:15 AM on weekdays; prepares a simple breakfast and packs lunches/snacks.
Does a quick 10-minute stretch while coffee brews, then wakes children gently with a song.
Leaves for preschool drop-off by 8:15 AM; uses transit or a short drive depending on weather.
Checks emails briefly on commute and flags urgent freelance client requests.
workday: At preschool: greets each child, runs circle time, oversees center rotations, documents milestones on classroom tablets.
Uses snack time to chat with parents arriving for pick-up and share quick updates.
Takes a 30–45 minute lunch, often at a bench outside or with coworkers in the staff room.
Handles small crises calmly (band-aid for scraped knee, settling an upset child with a quiet corner).
After preschool: picks up older child from a neighbor’s babysit swap or coordinates rides with spouse.
evening: Arrives home, prepares a simple dinner while playing soft music; family eats together when possible.
Baths and bedtime routine for children includes a short bilingual story, song, and a consistent nightlight routine.
Does 1–2 hours of freelance work after kids’ bedtime if needed, or uses that time for household tasks.
Calls or texts a parent or close friend weekly for emotional check-ins.
Prepares outfits and snacks for the next day and sets timers for laundry or bottles.
weekend: Saturday mornings often at the farmers market, then a park visit or longer outdoor activity.
Sunday is planning and reset day—meal prep, laundry, tidying play areas, and a relaxed family walk.
Meets with a small playgroup one morning a week for socialization and informal parenting support.
Occasional date night when grandparents or a babysitting co-op are available.

physical.general_condition: Generally healthy adult with normal mobility and energy fluctuating around parenting cycles.
physical.chronic_conditions: Mild asthma, manageable with an occasional albuterol inhaler during seasonal flares. Mild postpartum pelvic floor weakness after last pregnancy, working with a community physiotherapist.
physical.medications: Uses an as-needed inhaler for asthma; takes prenatal vitamins while breastfeeding (if applicable) and an occasional OTC pain reliever for headaches.
physical.reproductive_health: Two pregnancies carried to term, uncomplicated vaginal deliveries with standard postpartum follow-up. Currently breastfeeding/combination-feeding the younger child (as applicable).

mental.general_condition: Generally stable mental health, with periods of increased anxiety related to sleep deprivation and financial stress.
mental.history: Experienced mild postpartum blues after first child; received support through a parent group and spoke with a counselor for several months. Now practices preventive self-care (therapy check-ins, breathing exercises).
mental.care_routine: Has a low-cost sliding-scale therapist seen every 4–6 weeks as preventative; uses short guided meditations and community parenting groups for social support.
mental.red_flags_and_management: Aware of signs of more serious postpartum depression; would seek help promptly if needed given prior family history of anxiety.

health.healthcare_access: Uses a community health clinic for pediatric checkups, an in-network OB/pediatrician; chooses clinics with evening or weekend hours when possible. Keeps a small medical fund for co-pays and unexpected visits.

relationships.name: Marcus Harrington (spouse)
relationships.description: Married partner; steady, pragmatic, works as a systems technician for a municipal transit authority. Shares household responsibilities, handles many logistics for car maintenance and larger home-improvement tasks. Co-parents closely, but they negotiate division of labor—Erin handles most preschool schedules and meals while Marcus takes early-morning duties on weekends. They coordinate finances and have monthly budget meetings.

relationships.name: Ava Park-Harrington
relationships.description: Eldest child; curious, loves blocks and animals, enrolled in preschool three mornings a week. Sleeps through the night most nights, is beginning to show early literacy interest and loves being read to in Korean and English.

relationships.name: Jun Park-Harrington
relationships.description: Youngest child (1.5 years); clingy at times, loves water play. Nap-dependent and triggers most schedule adjustments.

relationships.name: Mrs. Hyejin Park (mother, lives in Atlanta)
relationships.description: Korean-born mother who visits several times a year. Provides cultural continuity and occasional childcare help. Shares recipes and Korean language songs with grandchildren.
relationships.relationship_tone: Supportive, can be traditional in childrearing opinions; Erin navigates differences with calm boundary-setting.

relationships.name: Chris and Lena Morales (neighbors and friends)
relationships.description: A couple with a 3-year-old who coordinate playdates and occasional babysitting swaps. Serve as a day-to-day social anchor in the building.

relationships.name: Work colleagues at Bright Beginnings
relationships.description: A small team of early-childhood educators who coordinate lesson planning and share materials; a trusted professional network for childcare advice and job referrals.

relationships.name: Freelance client network
relationships.description: Local small-business owners who provide periodic web work; some have become friends and exchange parenting tips.

relationships.name: Grandparents (Harrington side)
relationships.description: Live two hours away, visit for long weekends, occasionally watch children when available. Practical, calming presence who provide a different set of cultural stories.

other_facts: Born to a mixed-race household: Korean mother and Midwestern American father; childhood included bilingual phrases, holiday mixes (Seollal and Thanksgiving), and both types of food on the table.
Grew up in a mid-sized Midwestern city, moved to Portland in her mid-20s for community college and more job opportunities in education.
Met Marcus at a community volunteering event for a neighborhood cleanup on a rainy day; they bonded over shared thrift-store finds and mutual love of simple breakfasts.
Married in a small backyard ceremony with a mix of Korean and Western traditions—bowing ritual to parents and a casual brunch afterward.
Chose early childhood work after a transformative volunteer experience reading picture books at a public library, where she loved watching children's eyes light up.
Completed a front-end web bootcamp partly to increase household income and partly because she enjoys building practical websites for small businesses she cares about.
Keeps a digital photo album by year and prints a favorite family photo each month to put on the fridge—values tangible memories.
Once organized a preschool fundraiser that raised enough to buy new math manipulatives; felt deeply proud of the community effort.
Had a near-miss with a small rental kitchen fire years ago; since then she is extra careful with child safety around the stove and keeps a fire extinguisher accessible.
Maintains a small garden box on the building rooftop where she grows herbs and a couple of cherry tomatoes—teaches kids about food coming from soil.
Has a favorite children’s book, 'The Very Hungry Caterpillar,' she reads in both English and Korean, making silly voices that the kids adore.
Keeps a shared budgeting spreadsheet with Marcus and reviews finances monthly to avoid surprises and plan for daycare co-pays.
Once took a solo backpacking-style weekend trip with a close friend after the first maternity leave to recharge; credits it with preventing parental burnout.
Is comfortable haggling gently at flea markets for durable items and considers second-hand finds a trophy of successful parenting frugality.
Has a soft spot for simple craft projects: homemade play dough, water-color resist art, and sock puppets for storytelling sessions.
Experienced an instance of implicit bias in a previous job interview; it influenced her to mentor young women of color in the community college program.
Learned to sew from her mother; fixes small tears on kids' clothes and has made a few soft blankets for friends' newborns.
Frequently borrows and lends baby gear among friends, keeping a running inventory on a shared neighborhood app.
Is registered with a local babysitting co-op; credits it with enabling occasional couple time and socialization for the kids.
Keeps a 'first-aid/comfort' drawer with items for minor home emergencies and toddler comforts (thermometer, instant rice packs, favorite pacifier).
Almost always packs a small 'calm kit' for flights or long drives: a favorite book, sticker book, a squeezable sensory ball, and backup snacks.
Has a low-key morning ritual: a quick stretch, an americano (oat milk), five minutes of planning on the kitchen counter before the household wakes.
Was the first person in her family to pursue post-secondary education beyond high school, which she views with both pride and obligation.
Values small acts of household celebration: Friday pizza night, morning chitchat on Saturdays, and silly award tokens for children’s small achievements.
Uses name-pronunciation etiquette actively—teaches kids to ask and listen when meeting people of different backgrounds.
Has a tendency to keep sentimental small things: a hospital bracelet from each birth, a folded first onesie, the first tooth in a labeled envelope.
Once helped a neighbor navigate city rental paperwork and felt gratified by passing along pragmatic knowledge she’d learned.
Enjoys a few hobbies she returns to when time allows: listening to Korean pop playlists while cooking, short nature photography walks, and a knitting project kept for the future.

Is an active member of a local parenting forum where she trades recommendations for pediatricians, parks, and secondhand gear; she contributes reviews and notes about accessibility and stroller routes.
Ran a small personal project creating bilingual flashcards for preschoolers and shared them digitally with other parents; it was downloaded by several local families.
Has a small ceremonial dish she makes for holidays—a mild savory rice porridge—that bridges both cultures and is requested by in-laws.
Remembers, vividly, the first time she took Ava to the public library’s story hour and how nervous she felt meeting other parents; that day shaped her commitment to community-building.
Keeps a notebook of 'parenting hacks'—folding tips for diaper bags, the best nap-shade hacks for travel, favorite recipes—for quick reference and to pass to friends.
Has experienced apartment insecurity once (a landlord sold the unit) and thus prioritizes building good landlord relationships and saving for moving costs.
Believes rituals matter: a specific bedtime song used consistently so children associate it with calm and sleep.
Enjoys teaching basic Korean words through daily tasks (counting rice, naming colors) and feels proud when children spontaneously say a Korean word in the store.
Was part of a city-wide 'safe routes to parks' advocacy meeting and learned how small civic actions can change crosswalk timing and signage.
Keeps a small jar with coins marked for 'emergency childcare'—an accessible fund for unexpected sitter costs so they don't tap savings.
Has a childhood memory of learning to ride a bike on a cul-de-sac and uses that story to teach patience and practice to her own children.
Plans to document family stories with audio interviews of grandparents to preserve accents, recipes, and family narratives for future generations.
